Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Tissue-specific hydrogel for peripheral nerve repair
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the ability to more effectively treat nerve injuries. Each year in the United States alone there are about 600,000 surgical procedures performed to reconstruct peripheral nerves, with costs of more than $1.7B. In moderate to severe cases of peripheral nerve injury, such as those involving nerve transections, stretch, or crush, long-term outcomes are poor. Disabilities due to nerve injury are associated with more than $7B in costs of long-term care for those affected. Add to this the economic costs of lost productivity of these individuals and the total costs are in excess of $15B per year. The proposed work seeks to further develop and validate a novel technology which can have a significant impact upon clinical care for nerve injury by both speeding and improving nerve repair.

This I-Corps project is based upon multiple years of research demonstrating that peripheral nerve tissue derived hydrogels represent an ideal environment for nerve repair. Through multiple benchtop and preclinical tests, it has been shown that delivery of such hydrogels to a site of nerve repair modulates the inflammatory response to injury, recruits cells which are supportive of nerve repair, and ultimately supports the regrowth of neurons resulting in improved functional recovery. This solution has the potential to be used in multiple nerve injury modalities including nerve crush, stretch, transection, and gap injuries as either a primary treatment or as an adjunct to surgical repair and/or nerve grafting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: During the course of this project the team interviewed more than 100 physicians involved in surgical care of individuals with nerve injuries. The predominant specialties of surgeons performing peripheral nerve procedures included plastic surgeons, orthopedic surgeons, and neurosurgeons. During the course of these activities, we came to understand the needs of these individuals, the difficulties encountered by patients, and the benchmarks by which surgeons evaluate new technologies (i.e. level of evidence, animal models, clinical models, safety and efficacy versus cost). We also developed a robust understanding of current surgical practices, different approaches, and current technology used in nerve repair. Additionally, we spoke with multiple payers to better understand what makes technologies, such as the one we are proposing to develop, attractive to payers. We also spoke to many companies which are current providers in the nerve injury and repair space to better understand their product offerings and potential relationship or eventual acquisition opportunities. Lastly, we performed significant customer discover with the United States Military – a potential critical user of technologies affecting personnel injured in traumatic events.

Broader Impacts: The results of this in-depth customer discovery effort have significantly informed our product development strategy. We understand the limitations of current technologies, as well as the areas which the physicians who treat peripheral nerve injury see as unmet needs. As a result of our efforts, a start up company was formed.  This company was able to recruit key opinion leaders across all three specialties as advisors to the company and entered into discussions. These ongoing relationships allowed us to fine tune product development and receive rapid and valuable feedback during the course of development. Lastly, the discussions with commercial competitors have led to anumber of discussions regarding partnerships, potential manufacturing opportunities, and significant interest from those with products currently in the space. We continue to employ the customer discovery techniques learned during this process to improve and adjust our product development on a regular basis to meet user needs.
